name: Sid Meier's Railroads!
description: Sid Meier's Railroads! marks the return of the watershed title in simulation/strategy gaming that launched the popular "tycoon" genre, and inspired a new generation of games. Sid Meier's Railroads!
minimum_requirements: Minimum Windows 2000, Windows XP 1.4GHz Intel Pentium 4 or AMD Athlon processor or equivalent 512 MB RAM 64 MB Video card with hardware pixel and vertex shaders (GeForce 3, Radeon 8500 or better) DirectX 7 compatible sound card 1.7 GB of free disc drive space
recommended_requirements: Recommended Windows 2000, Windows XP 2.0 GHz Intel Pentium 4 or AMD Athlon processor or equivalent (or better) 1GB RAM 128MB videocard with pixel shader 2.0 support (Radeon x800, GeForce 6800) DirectX 7 compatible sound card 1.7 GB of free disc drive space

I've been playing Railroad Tycoon series since the first edition, yeah... that old one that looked like Civ I... This edition has pretty nice graphics. Very Easy to play. In less then a month I've manage to win in all levels. So if you're looking for a complex Railroad game, this is not for you. But if you have little time to spend playing games, I'd recomend this one. You can play the whole game in less then 1 hour. And still have a good amount of fun.
There are a lot of train games for the PC, but few are as lightweight and approachable as this one.

A gem of a transport/trade simulation game.   Simple mechanics - build rail lines -run trains - transport things and people - earn money - manage your finances - grow your company . After you start losing to AI bots - you start seeing the finer nuances that the game packs below that obvious layer of simplicity. The effects of terrain , random events ,the stock market , aggressive expansion slowly start to make sense. Like any Sid Meier classic- this one grows better with time.  Sadly, the multi-player aspect is gone . The graphics are surely out -of-date but in no way ugly. I had to download a patched file from pcgamingwiki - for a memory bug to be handled. Heck this game is old - ok ? It needs some help from you to run well on modern systems. But for me, the simple tweaks are totally worth the experience.  I wish this was remade today with Steam Workshop support and modern graphics - with no changes to the basic mechanics. Please Mr. Sid ... VOLVO PLS ?

A Game for Those Not Looking for a Tycoon-Level Game      I got this game as part of the Sid Meier's Humble Bundle. Having previously played Railroad Tycoon 3 extensively, I was looking forward to a modern sequel. However, this isn't a sequel.   This game is much less advanced in it's in -game economy, track types, consist editing, and locomotive selection. AI will also sometimes have issues traversing your track, getting stuck in loops, or not using low-congestion bypasses.   That's not to say it isn't fun. You can still enjoy playing against AI or others, but it's more causal train enthusiast level than armchair railroad president.   The graphics are nice, but neither advanced, nor detailed.   Textures aren't that high of a resolution, and steam locomotives lose their tenders for the game. Overall, enjoyable, but not deep.    + Ease of Use  + Art Style  + Gameplay  -------------------------  - Poor AI Routing  - Mechanics Lack Depth  - Graphics Could Be Better       Overall Score: 7/10   (Good)

This game is quite old, but still is one of the most fun games that I've ever enjoyed playing. It has difficulties accessing higher amounts of memory in current operating systems, but these difficulties are easily overcome with a simple download from a fan site. There are several fan sites out there, and they offer everything from new maps to historical livery for the trains. The module which permits the game to address higher memory also adds coal cars to the steam driven trains. Replay value is extremely high. The only question in my mind, especially considering what the sales figure as were, is why Sid Meier's has not issued an update perhaps with some additional content in it as he has done with his other great hits, such as the Civilization series. I loved Railroad Tycoon 3 and Railroad Tycoon 2, and I'd read enough negative reviews of this game comparing it to the RTC series that I held off on purchasing this game. Well, since it doesn't look like we're ever going to get a true Railroad Tycoon 4 and this game was on sale for $5.99 I decided, sure, it's not any more expensive than a Big Mac Value Meal, I'll give it a shot.   Well, I can say this game wasn't even worth the $5.99.  I knew the economic simulation of the RTC series wouldn't be present in this game - no fluctuating prices, no inefficient 'Tycoonatrons' moving materials and goods independent of railroad to simuate how the real world works, no independent industrial growth. That was fine. But there are only 6 or so types of raw materials, and demand never ceases so all you have to do is hook up more and more supply facilities to the cities. Oh and there's very few cities either, and no growth caps - Los Angeles and Tehachapi will both grow into 'Metropolises' once you give them their materials. The maps are TINY and build out very fast.  At first I was pleasantly surprised by some innovations Sid Meier has introduced to the track-building mechanics: Tracks and stations can go anywhere in cities, no more tedious weaving around or knocking down buildings to get your station into a city, or having to locate in a certain spot to cover as much of a sprawling city as possible. Just plop your track and station down and the buildings automatically move around to get out of your way! Wonderful! Unfortunately, the double track mechanic is awful and making parallel tracks connect to each other takes an act of God. I found myself constantly having to build switches between the parallel tracks, and even high priority trains stop every time they encounter a switch. Even worse, there is no undo button AND NO BULLDOZER BUTTON so once you build a track, you're stuck with it. My tracks looked like disorganized monstrosities because of this, with trains constantly bogging down at a dozen unnecessary switch signals. At least there aren't any sanding/water towers required here...but it really doesn't matter.  Once you get into a position to buy out your competitors, make sure to liquidate their assets rather than absorb them, because absorbing a well-established competitor will instantly bring the game (and I don't run a cheap system) to its' knees with freezes and eventual crashes, and that's what brought me back to this screen, completely fed up.  I don't know how this game got through the play-testing phase of development. The simplistic economy is a disappointment after the fantastic Railroad Tycoon 3 but I can handle it.... but the track building snafus are just awful, and overall I find this game just wasn't enjoyable even when it does operate smoothly. I hope we get a true successor to Railroad Tycoon 3 someday.

There are better train simulators out there. Railroads is a very basic, fast-paced, easy to learn game that unfortunately doesn't get very deep. Train routes play out basically the way they do in most railway simulators, but with a simplified commodity system. The rail-laying mechanic is finnicky and buggy, which is particulary annoying as it is the primary action of the game.   While increasing difficulty does offer more of a challenge, the mechanics simply aren't deep enough to keep me interested for more than a few games (which only take an hour or so to complete, which isn't an issue, but I mention in case someone saw 'Sid Meier' and thought games would be 7 hour long civ-like games).  In the end, there are much better transportation simulation programs out there

Are you looking for a 'Trains'-game? Something to lay out networks and make good profits from self-raised industries? Or are you looking for a model-train-simulator?  If the latter is what you aim for, Sid Meyers RailRoads is yours. The graphics are nice and theres even a good bit of tension when going against Opponents, trying to buy each other out first.  However, if you were expecting well developed tools to create delicate railnetworks, bustling Trainstations and elegant bypasses of your humming Cargohubs - stay away! I dont even mind that the maps are so tiny compared to todays standarts, but the crippled pathing tools just wont let you go to your fullest extent. Planning a longer route ahead? Cant do - build in intervalls and sell the last part of your rails again to try anew. Want an X-cross to enable trains switching track in one spot? No way. Even something simple as two trains heading the same direction on the same path? Unthinkable. And to top it all off? Its not running stable either. I had 2 crashes in not even a full hour.  It is a neat littly game for in-between i guess. Worth the 2,50 I gave at sale - I wouldnt spend more on it, though. Theres lots of better options than this and some are even free: Check OpenTTD if youre not afraid of pixels.

The game is fun and quite strategic, but I would love for Steam to stop allowing games that are not playable to be posted. I keep encountering games like Sid Meier's Railroads that allow you to play for a time before crashing. This game is not graphically or audio intensive, therefore I should not have any trouble playing it fully. The timing of the crash is not pinpointable because it happens at random times. Sometimes it's 5 minutes into gameplay or 45 minutes into gameplay. If you have Windows 8.1, you are more than likely going to encounter crashes. It's especially frustrating when you've built up a big network or railways and have not saved them only to have the game crash. I know I could have saved often to avoid the loss, but the point is a game should not be allowed to be sold no matter the price if it's not able to be played due to it being an older game. Re-release a fully playable version or do not release it at all. I loved this game in the times I could play, but the constant crashing drove me to a hard pass. I know you can get fixes online and if you can get them to work then more power to you. You shouldn't have to do a process of 'fixes', but you will more than likely have to.

If you excuse the semi-frequent crashing (easy to do if you set it to autosave every minute, so you never lose any progress), this is a rail tycoon game that has aged remarkably well. It's easy to set your own balance between building for profit and for fun, and the interface is really simple to use. You can also buy into and build up industries across each map and there are plenty of graphs and statistics handy for you to keep a close eye on your progress. The graphics still work well even in full screen, and the sound is great.  It's just a shame that this game has never been updated. I think a version of this with better graphics, online multiplayer, and mods through Steam Workshop (for extra maps, engines, and industries) would do really well - it has the world renowned Sid Meier name on it, after all.

This is a great game when you want a break from FPS games. Much like Sid Meier's Civilization this game subtly teaches a bit of railway history. This game is not a Railway Sim game that you need to aquire the keen skills of driving a train.  Most of the time I have played this game in single player mode againts 3 A.I. players. The A.I. can be ruthless when playing playing at hard levels. The A.I. generally doesn't waste money and calculates the best return on investment. With a bit of strategy you can compete for the same resources making it more costly for them to operate.  I have played this game on a LAN with four players. Multiplayer game play feels more like a single player map early on, Once you have expanded you railway empire, it starts to get really interesting as you complete for the same limited resources.   The game may eventually crash after all the players railways have grown very large. You will need to find the 3GB Ram fix to make the game work with large complex maps. There are a number of community maps / mods that can be really fun to play and introduce you to new areas of the world.  After playing Sid Meier's Civilization I found zooming out to see a larger area (FOV) of the map is very limited. This is somewhat like using a flashight in a cave, you only see small areas of what may be an enormous space.  Maybe one day they may entertain the idea of developing a Sid Meier's Railroad 2.

My first ever game was Railroad Tycoon II, back when I was still in elementary school. I had basically no idea what I was doing in terms of economics or strategy, but I would waste hours and hours just making the little trains go 'round the map. It was a simpler time and a happy time, and Sid Meier's Railroads! absolutely lives up to my memories. Yes, it has its flaws - certainly, the track-laying could have used some work, and I would have loved more customizability with the trains themselves, but overall, here we have in my computer the simple joy of setting up a model train set and watching it go. I play this, and there's that same sense of childlike wonder all over again that I had when I was actually eight years old.
